content:
I've edited the puzzle just now:

Goal
* Reformatted 5x5 and 0 as {{constants}} instead of [[variables]].

Input
* Reformatted "n*5".

* Moved '("free space" is signified with a 0)' from Constraints section to here.

* Changed "Line n*5+2" to "Next line".

Constraints
* Changed upper limit of n from 10000 to 100 because that's the maximum n among all the cases.

Stub generator
* Fixed the stub generator re Stilgart's comment below and yhuberla's comment on the forum ( https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-bingo/187348/15 ).

LVdA  on #generalFR says that there is an issue with the stub generator. Indeed, only n (instead of 5*n) lines are read in order to retrieve the grids.

In my opinion, this is minor since this puzzle is a community puzzle (and not a clash).
Moreover, the best solution I see would be to put five copies of Line 2, so that the last read actually do the read for the last input line. But this is far from satisfactory. :(
Whereas C may be fast enough to solve such enormous test cases, other languages may not. I suggest you reduce the size of the test cases. Problem is good though

Really? I was disappointed by the size limit of the test cases, since my c# solution was still handling 10,000 in under 1 second - my original sizes were 1, 10, 100, 1000 & 10,000, until I noticed the character limit. Are there really languages that will struggle with this?

I do hope that CyberLemonade was joking.

Many of us are disappointed by the size limit. Because of this, many interesting problems can be solved in any language with suboptimal solutions.

My two cents: I've managed to answer in bytecode Ocaml without any problem nor optimization. I can hardly imagine a (reasonable) langage slower than Ocaml bytecode in this situation. I suggest you can put more complex test case (at least the 1000 players one)

I managed to test 25,000 cards without difficulty.
really no optimization.
my script continues to check after finding the solution
no problem for me
Is this a joke ? Just print the time difference between start and stop of your program on stderr.

Don't know how to do that, maybe you could elaborate?
And sorry everyone for my misjudgement of time allotted

You should consider tackling more puzzles from the (multiplayer) bot programming section. This section is a good place to learn how to handle a time limit and to appreciate the number of operations one can achieve within very limited time. ;)
